content.description:
30 feet downhill from the ‘Great Briar Roof’ is another roof at the same height. 

Pitch 1: Climb up a left-facing arete toward a crack in the upper roof. Work your way toward the chimney. Belay here. 

Pitch 2: Exit up and into the chimney then a finger jam crack out of the roof. Continue up the slab above to a large cedar tree. Rappel here.
content.protection: Standard gap rack: Small to medium cams, 2 large cams, set of stoppers, few small tri-cams.

climbs.name: Seam of Fear
climbs.fa: Aid FA: 1997 Mark Ronca & Matt Hill, FFA: 2005 Joey Vulpis & Jen Napolitano

content.description: This route starts 5 feet right of ‘Jungle Warfare’ on a roof with a bush growing out of it. Crimp up the thin seam (or aid up it) toward a small crimping edge. Crank out the moves on the slab through the tiers and up to the cedar rappel tree. I believe I was the first to free climb this route as it was done as an aid route previously on the past. The moves are calculated and interesting but easy to figure out if the wall is clean. This wall sees little to no traffic these days.
content.protection: Standard gap rack: Small to medium cams, 2 large cams, set of stoppers, few small tri-cams.   Aid: knifeblades, aluminum and copper heads and hooks.

climbs.name: Pray for Life
climbs.fa: Aid FA: 1997 Mark Ronca, FFA: Joey Vulpis 2002

content.description: This route starts 10 feet right of the previous route. It has several left-facing dihedrals. Work your way up and through the dihedrals and arete. Continue climbing until you come to the flake. Work the flake on its left side to the top (small protection). Continue up and through the roof above. Work your way into the upper dihedral and over the edge. Traverse left to the cedar rappel tree.
content.protection: Standard gap rack: Small to medium cams, 2 large cams, set of stoppers, few small tri-cams.   Aid: knifeblades, several lost arrows and small wires.

climbs.name: Jungle Warfare
climbs.fa: Aid: 1997 Matt Hill & Mark Ronca FFA: Joey Vulpis & Jen Napolitano 2005

content.description: This route starts on the left side of the ‘Great Briar’ ledge. Climb up the slab then out toward the left-facing arete. Continue up the crack through an overhang. Continue up and traverse right to a cedar tree. Rappel here. You can continue up the slab to another large cedar tree.
content.protection: Standard gap rack: Small to medium cams, 2 large cams, set of stoppers, few small tri-cams.

content.description: This route starts 10 feet right of the ‘Great Briar Roof’. Climb up the middle of the long, horizontal roof on the thing crack that widens toward the edge of the roof.
content.protection: Standard gap rack: Small to medium cams, 2 large cams, set of stoppers, few small tri-cams.

climbs.name: Driving Excitement
climbs.fa: Aid FA: 1997 Mark Ronca, FFA: Joey Vulpis 2002

content.description: This route starts 5 feet right of ‘Seam of Fear’. Follow the thin seam up and left. Pull the upper edge on small crimpers and edges. Work your way left and join up with ‘Seam of Fear’ or continue up the tiered slab for some difficult moves. Another route I believe I was the first to free climb back in the early 2000’s.
content.protection: Standard gap rack: Small to medium cams, 2 large cams, set of stoppers, few small tri-cams.   Aid: knifeblades, hooks and aluminum and copper heads.

content.description: This wall starts about 125 feet to the right of the ‘Zombie Wall’. It’s a series of roof systems for about 20 feet on the wall. Smear the slab at the base to reach a nice belay ledge to start the routes. Several first free ascents were done by Joey Vulpis, Jen Napolitano and others in the early to mid-2000's.
